scene.title: V

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Is no one laughing? no one drinking?
I'll teach you how to grin, I'm thinking.
To-day you're like wet straw, so tame;
And usually you're all aflame.

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: Now that's your fault; from you we nothing see,
No beastliness and no stupidity.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.stage: (Pours a glass of wine over BRANDER'S head.)
sp.line: There's both together!

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: Twice a swine!

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: You wanted them: I've given you mine.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Turn out who quarrels—out the door!
With open throat sing chorus, drink and roar!
Up! holla! ho!

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Woe's me, the fearful bellow!
Bring cotton, quick! He's split my ears, that fellow.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: When the vault echoes to the song,
One first perceives the bass is deep and strong.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Well said! and out with him that takes the least offence!
Ah, tara, lara da!

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Ah, tara, lara, da!

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: The throats are tuned, commence!
sp.stage: (Sings.)
sp.line: The dear old holy Roman realm,
How does it hold together?

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: A nasty song! Fie! a political song—
A most offensive song! Thank God, each morning, therefore,
That you have not the Roman realm to care for!
At least, I hold it so much gain for me,
That I nor Chancellor nor Kaiser be.
Yet also we must have a ruling head, I hope,
And so we'll choose ourselves a Pope.
You know the quality that can
Decide the choice, and elevate the man.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.stage: (sings)
sp.line: Soar up, soar up, Dame Nightingale!
Ten thousand times my sweetheart hail!

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: No, greet my sweetheart not! I tell you, I'll resent it.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: My sweetheart greet and kiss! I dare you to prevent it!

scene.line: Draw the latch! the darkness makes:
Draw the latch! the lover wakes.
Shut the latch! the morning breaks

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Yes, sing away, sing on, and praise, and brag of her!
I'll wait my proper time for laughter:
Me by the nose she led, and now she'll lead you after.
Her paramour should be an ugly gnome,
Where four roads cross, in wanton play to meet her:
An old he-goat, from Blocksberg coming home,
Should his good-night in lustful gallop bleat her!
A fellow made of genuine flesh and blood
Is for the wench a deal too good.
Greet her? Not I: unless, when meeting,
To smash her windows be a greeting!

scene.line: BRANDER (pounding on the table)
Attention! Hearken now to me!
Confess, Sirs, I know how to live.
Enamored persons here have we,
And I, as suits their quality,
Must something fresh for their advantage give.
Take heed! 'Tis of the latest cut, my strain,
And all strike in at each refrain!
There was a rat in the cellar-nest,
Whom fat and butter made smoother:
He had a paunch beneath his vest
Like that of Doctor Luther.
The cook laid poison cunningly,
And then as sore oppressed was he
As if he had love in his bosom.

sp.speaker: CHORUS (shouting)
sp.line: As if he had love in his bosom!

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: He ran around, he ran about,
His thirst in puddles laving;
He gnawed and scratched the house throughout.
But nothing cured his raving.
He whirled and jumped, with torment mad,
And soon enough the poor beast had,
As if he had love in his bosom.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.line: As if he had love in his bosom!

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: And driven at last, in open day,
He ran into the kitchen,
Fell on the hearth, and squirming lay,
In the last convulsion twitching.
Then laughed the murderess in her glee:
"Ha! ha! he's at his last gasp," said she,
"As if he had love in his bosom!"

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.line: As if he had love in his bosom!

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: How the dull fools enjoy the matter!
To me it is a proper art
Poison for such poor rats to scatter.

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: Perhaps you'll warmly take their part?

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: The bald-pate pot-belly I have noted:
Misfortune tames him by degrees;
For in the rat by poison bloated
His own most natural form he sees.

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: Before all else, I bring thee hither
Where boon companions meet together,
To let thee see how smooth life runs away.
Here, for the folk, each day's a holiday:
With little wit, and ease to suit them,
They whirl in narrow, circling trails,
Like kittens playing with their tails?
And if no headache persecute them,
So long the host may credit give,
They merrily and careless live.

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: The fact is easy to unravel,
Their air's so odd, they've just returned from travel:
A single hour they've not been here.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: You've verily hit the truth! Leipzig to me is dear:
Paris in miniature, how it refines its people!

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Who are the strangers, should you guess?

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Let me alone! I'll set them first to drinking,
And then, as one a child's tooth draws, with cleverness,
I'll worm their secret out, I'm thinking.
They're of a noble house, that's very clear:
Haughty and discontented they appear.

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: They're mountebanks, upon a revel.

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Look out, I'll smoke them now!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES (to FAUST)
sp.line: Not if he had them by the neck, I vow,
Would e'er these people scent the Devil!
FAUST Fair greeting, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Our thanks: we give the same.
sp.stage: (Murmurs, inspecting MEPHISTOPHELES from the side.)
sp.line: In one foot is the fellow lame?

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: Is it permitted that we share your leisure?
In place of cheering drink, which one seeks vainly here,
Your company shall give us pleasure.

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: A most fastidious person you appear.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: No doubt 'twas late when you from Rippach started?
And supping there with Hans occasioned your delay?

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: We passed, without a call, to-day.
At our last interview, before we parted
Much of his cousins did he speak, entreating
That we should give to each his kindly greeting.
sp.stage: (He bows to FROSCH.)
sp.line: ALTMAYER (aside)
You have it now! he understands.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: A knave sharp-set!

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Just wait awhile: I'll have him yet.

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: If I am right, we heard the sound
Of well-trained voices, singing chorus;
And truly, song must here rebound
Superbly from the arches o'er us.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Are you, perhaps, a virtuoso?

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: O no! my wish is great, my power is only so-so.

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Give us a song!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: If you desire, a number.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: So that it be a bran-new strain!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: We've just retraced our way from. Spain,
The lovely land of wine, and song, and slumber.
sp.stage: (Sings.)
sp.line: There was a king once reigning,
Who had a big black flea—

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Hear, hear! A flea! D'ye rightly take the jest?
I call a flea a tidy guest.

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES (sings)
sp.line: There was a king once reigning,
Who had a big black flea,
And loved him past explaining,
As his own son were he.
He called his man of stitches;
The tailor came straightway:
Here, measure the lad for breeches.
And measure his coat, I say!

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: But mind, allow the tailor no caprices:
Enjoin upon him, as his head is dear,
To most exactly measure, sew and shear,
So that the breeches have no creases!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: In silk and velvet gleaming
He now was wholly drest—
Had a coat with ribbons streaming,
A cross upon his breast.
He had the first of stations,
A minister's star and name;
And also all his relations
Great lords at court became.
And the lords and ladies of honor
Were plagued, awake and in bed;
The queen she got them upon her,
The maids were bitten and bled.
And they did not dare to brush them,
Or scratch them, day or night:
We crack them and we crush them,
At once, whene'er they bite.

sp.speaker: CHORUS (shouting)
sp.line: We crack them and we crush them,
At once, whene'er they bite!
FROSCH Bravo! bravo! that was fine.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Every flea may it so befall!

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: Point your fingers and nip them all!

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Hurrah for Freedom! Hurrah for wine!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: I fain would drink with you, my glass to Freedom clinking,
If 'twere a better wine that here I see you drinking.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Don't let us hear that speech again!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: Did I not fear the landlord might complain,
I'd treat these worthy guests, with pleasure,
To some from out our cellar's treasure.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Just treat, and let the landlord me arraign!

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: And if the wine be good, our praises shall be ample.
But do not give too very small a sample;
For, if its quality I decide,
With a good mouthful I must be supplied.

scene.line: ALTMAYER (aside)
They're from the Rhine! I guessed as much, before.

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: Bring me a gimlet here!

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: What shall therewith be done?
You've not the casks already at the door?

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Yonder, within the landlord's box of tools, there's one!
MEPHISTOPHELES (takes the gimlet)
sp.stage: (To FROSCH.)
sp.line: Now, give me of your taste some intimation.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: How do you mean? Have you so many kinds?

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: The choice is free: make up your minds.
ALTMAYER (to FROSCH)
Aha! you lick your chops, from sheer anticipation.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Good! if I have the choice, so let the wine be Rhenish!
Our Fatherland can best the sparkling cup replenish.

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.stage: (boring a hole in the edge of the table, at the place where FROSCH sits)
sp.line: Get me a little wax, to make the stoppers, quick!

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Ah! I perceive a juggler's trick.
sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES (to BRANDER)
sp.line: And you?

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: Champagne shall be my wine,
And let it sparkle fresh and fine!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.stage: (bores: in the meantime one has made the wax stoppers, and plugged the holes with them.)

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: What's foreign one can't always keep quite clear of,
For good things, oft, are not so near;
A German can't endure the French to see or hear of,
Yet drinks their wines with hearty cheer.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.stage: (as MEPHISTOPHELES approaches his seat)
sp.line: For me, I grant, sour wine is out of place;
Fill up my glass with sweetest, will you?
MEPHISTOPHELES (boring)
Tokay shall flow at once, to fill you!

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: No—look me, Sirs, straight in the face!
I see you have your fun at our expense.

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: O no! with gentlemen of such pretence,
That were to venture far, indeed.
Speak out, and make your choice with speed! With what a vintage can I serve you?

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: With any—only satisfy our need.
sp.stage: (After the holes have been bored and plugged)
sp.line: MEPHISTOPHELES (with singular gestures)
Grapes the vine-stem bears,
Horns the he-goat wears!
The grapes are juicy, the vines are wood,
The wooden table gives wine as good!
Into the depths of Nature peer,—
Only believe there's a miracle here!
Now draw the stoppers, and drink your fill!

scene.sp: ALL (as they draw out the stoppers, and the wine which has been desired flows into the glass of each) O beautiful fountain, that flows at will!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: But have a care that you nothing spill!
sp.stage: (They drink repeatedly.)
sp.line: ALL (sing)
As 'twere five hundred hogs, we feel
So cannibalic jolly!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: See, now, the race is happy—it is free!

sp.speaker: FAUST
sp.line: To leave them is my inclination.

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: Take notice, first! their bestiality
Will make a brilliant demonstration.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.stage: (drinks carelessly: the wine spills upon the earth, and turns to flame)
sp.line: Help! Fire! Help! Hell-fire is sent!
sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES (charming away the flame)
sp.line: Be quiet, friendly element!
sp.stage: (To the revellers)
sp.line: A bit of purgatory 'twas for this time, merely.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: What mean you? Wait!—you'll pay for't dearly!
You'll know us, to your detriment.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Don't try that game a second time upon us!

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: I think we'd better send him packing quietly.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: What, Sir! you dare to make so free,
And play your hocus-pocus on us!

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES
sp.line: Be still, old wine-tub.

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Broomstick, you!
You face it out, impertinent and heady?

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: Just wait! a shower of blows is ready.

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.stage: (draws a stopper out of the table: fire flies in his face.)
sp.line: I burn! I burn!

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: 'Tis magic! Strike—
The knave is outlawed! Cut him as you like!
sp.stage: (They draw their knives, and rush upon MEPHISTOPHELES.)

sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES (with solemn gestures)
sp.line: False word and form of air,
Change place, and sense ensnare!
Be here—and there!
sp.stage: (They stand amazed and look at each other.)

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Where am I? What a lovely land!

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Vines? Can I trust my eyes?

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: And purple grapes at hand!

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: Here, over this green arbor bending,
See what a vine! what grapes depending!
sp.stage: (He takes SIEBEL by the nose: the others do the same reciprocally, and raise their knives.)
sp.speaker: MEPHISTOPHELES (as above)
sp.line: Loose, Error, from their eyes the band,
And how the Devil jests, be now enlightened!
sp.stage: (He disappears with FAUST: the revellers start and separate.)

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: What happened?

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: How?

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: Was that your nose I tightened?

sp.speaker: BRANDER (to SIEBEL)
sp.line: And yours that still I have in hand?

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: It was a blow that went through every limb!
Give me a chair! I sink! my senses swim.

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: But what has happened, tell me now?

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: Where is he? If I catch the scoundrel hiding,
He shall not leave alive, I vow.

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: I saw him with these eyes upon a wine-cask riding
Out of the cellar-door, just now.
Still in my feet the fright like lead is weighing.
sp.stage: (He turns towards the table.)
sp.line: Why! If the fount of wine should still be playing?

sp.speaker: SIEBEL
sp.line: 'Twas all deceit, and lying, false design!

sp.speaker: FROSCH
sp.line: And yet it seemed as I were drinking wine.

sp.speaker: BRANDER
sp.line: But with the grapes how was it, pray?

sp.speaker: ALTMAYER
sp.line: Shall one believe no miracles, just say!
